reviewText: Great movie. I liked how different the war in here is: e.g. 2 opponents are friends, fighting each other with armies, but not to death, heck..not even punching one another, but just being kind and smiling and joking. While it can sound wrong, it actually is some good stuff. No violence, but action. Even enemies aren't called bad words, nor do Americans act arrogant towards other countries. In other words, unlike many other movies, it gives lots of good atmosphere.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You have to go into this movie with the proper mind-set.  It's cheesy '80's action, with Barry Bostwick as the the wise-guy, bad-ass leader of an elite group of international soldiers.  This was my absolute favorite movie when I was 10, mostly because of the crazy vehicles - the dune buggies with light-sensitive color-changing camouflage were pretty rad, but the absolute best part was the rocket-launching motorcycles that you had to ride a wheelie on to shoot effectively!  (Yes, as I type it, I realize how horrendous it is, but by the same token, IT'S AWESOME!)I won't ruin the end, but you really, really, REALLY need to see the final few minutes of this film to truly appreciate the majesty that is Barry Bostwick on an amazingly green-screened motorcycle doing impossible things.
summary: Possibly the greatest movie since Citizen Kane

reviewText: Spread the cheese!!!! Someone should release this classic 80s action flick! As one reviewer pointed out, MegaForce mirrors US' post 9/11 strategy, it might be DubYah's favorite movie.What I remember about this movie when I saw it as a kid, was the cool rocket-firing motorcycles (which later appeared in the PC game Command & Conquer), the dune buggies (which became real in the US Army's Fast Attack Vehicle) and other fantastic military hardware. Also, no bullet nor projectile can't touch Barry Bostwick despite in a motorcycle without any armor!  And as far as I remember, they were facing a Mexican dictator! How's that for fostering good relations with your neighbors?My memory of this movie is rather sketchy, but I knew I loved it so please I want to relive my more innocent days and please release this on DVD!!!! Get Megaforce and watch it back to back with GI Joe the movie!
summary: This film should be on DVD!

reviewText: For those viewers already familiar with the live-action "G.I. Joe" film made a few years ago, one can imagine that movie's mega-million dollar budget.  Now, picture that same kind of movie being made thirty years ago for a few measly dollars and there you would have the schlock classic "Megaforce." As an impressionable kid, I was simply wowed by this film's awesome vehicles, the battle scenes, and even its incredibly cheesy storyline.  If you can find this vintage 1980's guy movie for a reasonable price, I highly recommend it for both camp action fans and for the pre-teen boy crowd to enjoy ninety minutes of sheer lame fun and possibly unintentional laughs.Directed by 1970's-80's stunt master Hal Needham, this clunker is actually something of a rarity since Burt Reynolds is absent despite repeatedly teaming up with Needham for "Smokey & the Bandit;" "The Cannonball Run I and II;""Stroker Ace;" and the underrated "Hooper."  Perhaps Reynolds simply wasn't available or just maybe for once he knew better than to show up here.  Instead, Barry ("The Rocky Horror Picture Show") Bostwick inexplicably steps in to play hero Colonel Ace Hunter (yes, that is the hero's name) complete with a peroxide blonde pompadour and beard; beige spandex; and even a light blue headband for good measure.  Also appearing are the late Edward (TV's "Knight Rider") Mulhare; the late Persis ("Star Trek: The Motion Picture") Khambatta; and Michael (TV's "Houston Knights") Beck, who must be given at least some credit for keeping relatively straight faces throughout this turkey.  Despite the grade-Z script, typecast actor Henry Silva gives a wily effort in yet another turn as a generic villain.The premise involves a super-elite, international anti-terrorist army going into battle to prevent an overseas invasion led by a mercenary ex-crony (Silva) of hero Ace Hunter (Bostwick).  Silva and Bostwick (whose suspiciously squeaky voice suggests it was badly dubbed) make the laugh-out-loud sub-plot involving a stolen cigarette lighter between them worth some good chuckles.  Not to mention Bostwick's utterly hilarious escape to a cargo plane via his flying motorcycle (let's just say it is some pretty primitive blue screen action).  Still, despite the movie's considerable failings, it retains a zany sense of humor that makes one think "Megaforce" is really an entertaining spoof of today's big-budget, often mindless action movies.  In that sense, "Megaforce" does for action movies what the Zucker Brothers comedies "Airplane!" and "The Naked Gun" did in wildly ridiculing 1970's disaster and police melodrama genres.Lastly, if you want to set up a cult classic double-feature, a great choice is 1979 TV cult spoof "Legends of the Super Heroes" now on DVD featuring Adam (Batman) West and Burt (Robin) Ward in their final appearances as the Dynamic Duo.Rating: 4/5 (Memorable quote from Ace Hunter taunting the villain: "The good guys always win ... even in the eighties!").

reviewText: After years of having to deal with sub-standard bootlegs of this classic piece of early 80's action cheese, Hen's Tooth Video has finally pulled off what seemed up till this point to be an impossible task of releasing an official Megaforce DVD in anamorphic widescreen. Fans of this 1982 film can finally breathe a sigh of relief!As for the film itself, it was supposed to have been one of the big releases during the summer of 1982 and managed to have toys as well as an Atari 2600 game released alongside the film. Asian studio Golden Harvest (who made and released most of Jackie Chan's classic films during the 80's and early to mid 90's) sunk 20 million dollars into Megaforce and were viewing it as their big attempt to break into American big summer release filmmaking but the movie tanked in spectacular fashion grossing less than 6 million dollars. By any definition of what makes a truly good movie, Megaforce is pretty bad. But for lovers like myself of cheesy movies that are so bad that they wind up being hugely entertaining, Megaforce is a B movie fan's dream. The movie has its fans though and have had to put up with years of horrible VHS quality bootleg DVD's and it seemed like the movie had completely fallen by the wayside and would never see a proper release of any kind.The DVD by Hen's Tooth Video was done from the original camera negative and presented in 1.78:1 anamorphic video. If your HDTV has some kind of "screen fit" option instead of 16:9, it will still fill up your screen and is how I recommend watching it so that no picture information is cropped off. The picture quality is very high quality with nice color saturation throughout. While it's a small shame that they didn't also do a blu-ray release too, the DVD looks great and is like seeing the movie for the 1st time all over again. There had been a Dutch DVD a few years back that was widescreen but it wasn't anamorphic so hats off to Hen's Tooth Video for finally giving this film a proper release. The sound is in 2 channel stereo and there are also English subtitles too. One odd thing with the audio is that it is for some reason pitched higher than it should be. Why this occured I have no idea but it isn't overly distracting to me at least. Sadly, the release is completely barebones with not even the theatrical trailer being listed. But considering that I thought that we would never get an official release of this film on DVD at all, I'm not going to complain much at all.So I highly recommend that fans pick up the DVD and let's hope that an eventual blu ray release will occur at some point in the near future. Deeds not words!!!
summary: This review pertains to the Hen's Tooth Video official DVD.

reviewText: I have been haunting sites that sell DVDs for years waiting for this movie to be released.  It has been on VHS for awhile but for some reason took a while to come out on DVD.  This is one the best examples of 80s camp around.  Barry Bostwick in skin tight gold lame, gold headband with blond locks flowing, riding around on a souped up motorcycle and grinning beyond belief.  Because it was made in the 80s there is no CG just very obvious photoshop and bad set designs.  The plot line is some unknown middle eastern (I assume) army being harrassed by a gloriously bad mercenary and they reach out to our heros for help.  Our heros are members of an elite, unknown special forces with all the good toys band of soldiers.  They even have their own James Bond type Q.  The acting in the movie is so campy and bad you can't help but smile the entire time you are watching it.  I've never figured out if the movie was meant to be taken seriously or meant to be camp but from the first time I saw it (most likely on HBO) I fell in love with it.  It is just so darn full of bad special effects, bad acting, bad costumes, bad dialoge and bad jokes that you just can't help but love it.There have been a number of reviews that mention the DVD itself was flawed but possibly was re-mastered because we had no problems with it on a Blu-ray player.Anyone who enjoys a good old fashioned romp with men in skin tight leotards, futuristic toys which are badly disguised tanks, motocyles and guns, explosions and crashes, cheesy acting and a bad script, this is your movie.
summary: A good campy movie for a rainy day

reviewText: For those curious about the audio issue, I just ordered this straight from Amazon and my DVD's audio is just fine.  Seems the corrected versions are in stock, so feel free to order away!As for the movie itself, its an amazing laugh riot that comes very close to being a Zucker Bros-esque parody of action films.  That it manages to achieve this completely unintentionally only adds to the fun.  Cheesey wonderful crap that only gets better the more you watch it.  Wait for the motorcycle scene at the end.  It will be something you will never EVER forget!  Makes the special effects in David Hasslehoff's "Hooked On A Feeling" music video look like freakin' Avatar.It looks great, too, fantastic looking picture on this DVD, way better than the VHS dub I watched on YouTube.Now if someone would put out a nice looking, restored DVD of "R.O.T.O.R." my life would be complete.

reviewText: MegaForce (Hal Needham, 1982)When I was in high school, 707's end title track to this flick was one of those songs that wasn't quite in light rotation on the local hard rock station; it got play, but you'd catch it maybe once a month. And when I was thirteen, man, that song was cool. Obviously, I wanted to see the movie. But I never got around to it; I don't remember whether it didn't play in Pittsburgh long enough for me to get there or whether I couldn't convince anyone to go with me. It's almost thirty years later, and I've finally seen the movie; I now suspect the latter reason.Ace Hunter (Barry Bostwick, whose career has been reduced to doing crap like Hannah Montana: The Movie) is the head of MegaForce, a high-tech mercenary unit. They get involved in a border war between two mythical middle eastern countries at the behest of Edward Byrne-White (Edward Mulhare, slumming it) and his sidekick Major Zara (Persis Khambatta, who looked damned good in a uniform). You've seen two or three eighties action movies, you know what's going to happen here. And it does. The only difference between this and a generic Schwarzenegger flick is the high-tech gadgets, which look incredibly dated now, and that fact that no one could persuade Schwarzenegger to lend his pecs to the production. There's a great turn by Henry Silva (The Manchurian Candidate, Ghost Dog) as the villain, but other than that, you're better off avoiding this turkey. Laughable script, wooden acting, bad special effects. I'm amazed the Sci-Fi Channel isn't showing it regularly, it's right up their alley. *

reviewText: Megaforce was shown on cable tv constantly durring the mid '80s in a vain effort to fill up airtime in the afternoon for kids. While I am sure the people behind the film believed they were making a decent action film for kids, the acting is hyperactive, sappy and bad and would never convince a kid of any age.Lots of folks love this film just because it IS that bad....and maybe one of the worst every made. Bad as it is, I could never watch it again.
summary: Not all cheese flicks are watchable again

reviewText: "Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone", "Yor: The Hunter from the Future", "Howling II: Werewolf Bi**h".  Child's play! You think you've seen cheese??  You have not seen cheese until you've seen Barry Bostwick with a blow-wave haircut wearing a gold spandex jumpsuit and purple (purple!!) headband ride a souped-up battle-cycle THROUGH THE AIR after a military airplane. All set to patriotic disco music.This movie is so great. I recall seeing it when it came out (I was 11) and feeling embaressed by what I was watching. And I was still watching cartoons at this point. There is only one other movie I can say that about - "Ator: The Fighting Eagle". Another great one.I love these movies. And you should to. You really need to buy this. There's something about Megaforce. Some inner life it contains all its own. In fact, reading these words right now RIGHT NOW can't you feel an inner pull, an inner need to buy this film. To click and buy. There is an energy emanating from these words up into your eyes and into your brain directing you to click and buy click and buy click and buy click and buy.JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us JOIN US join us
summary: The Taj Mahal of cheesy movies
